intro: Callirhoe involucrata f. incisa, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sandmat, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, characterized by its showy, pink to red flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and often have a distinctive incised or notched appearance, giving it its specific epithet. The species is adapted to drought conditions and is often found in disturbed or open habitats.
